(Reuters) - McGraw-Hill Education is planning an initial public offering (IPO) as early as the fourth quarter of this year, potentially valuing the textbook company at around $5 billion, including debt, according to people familiar with the matter.

The company’s owner, private equity firm Apollo Global Management LLC (APO.N), has held talks with investment banks about the IPO, though their underwriter roles will not be finalized before the summer, four people said this week.

It competes with Pearson Plc (PSON.L) and Cengage Learning Inc, and, like its peers, has sought to make most of its offerings available on the Internet as more people read books on tablets and phones.
New York-based company McGraw-Hill Education is one of the largest educational publishers in the world, selling textbooks for school and university students and professionals in about 60 languages.
McGraw-Hill Education would aim to go public near the end of the year, following the back-to-school season when it generates the bulk of its revenue through textbook sales, the people added.
Last year, McGraw-Hill Education generated $321 million in earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortization on revenue of $1.3 billion.
A spokesman for McGraw-Hill Education did not immediately respond to a request for a comment, while a spokesman for Apollo declined to comment.
Another educational publisher, Houghton Mifflin Harcourt Co (HMHC.O), went public in November 2013 after it emerged from bankruptcy.
Since then, Apollo has increased the company’s profits and made its digital offerings more popular, and cutting costs.
Apollo has also had the company borrow to pay it hefty dividends, recouping its $1 billion equity investment.
Apollo acquired the business from McGraw-Hill Companies in March 2013 for $2.4 billion.
Its shares have risen more than 60 percent since its IPO.
The company has $1.5 billion in debt as a result.
